references: The number of records in A is nAsubscriptğ‘›ğ´n_{A}, the number of records (rows) in B is nBsubscriptğ‘›ğµn_{B} and nAâ‰¤nBsubscriptğ‘›ğ´subscriptğ‘›ğµn_{A}\leq n_{B}, without loss of generality. Table 3 gives the undiscretized and discretized comparison data for the toy datafiles in Table 1, where first name and last name distance are each discretized into four bins (Lf=4subscriptğ¿ğ‘“4L_{f}=4), and year of birth distance is discretized into four bins (Lf=4subscriptğ¿ğ‘“4L_{f}=4).

references: A related problem occurs when one datafile is significantly larger than the other (nA<<nBmuch-less-thansubscriptğ‘›ğ´subscriptğ‘›ğµn_{A}<<n_{B}), and more generally when nBsubscriptğ‘›ğµn_{B} is very large, such that there are large numbers of observably identical or near-identical records in ğğ\mathbf{B}. The presence of false positives resulting from large nBsubscriptğ‘›ğµn_{B} tends to reduce both accuracy and the number of true matches recovered. Relatively small nAsubscriptğ‘›ğ´n_{A} aggravates the problem as records missing in the smaller population cannot provide information that would help assign remaining records. Table 2 illustrates this with a toy example.

references: In settings where record-specific parameters are not feasible, we propose including a disagreement level in the comparison data to indicate record pairs that have exact matches on common first names. This is done by constructing the comparison data as usual, then relabeling rows with exact matches on common names with the new disagreement level. Table 4 shows the modified comparison data when record pairs both with the first name â€œJohnâ€ are given their own disagreement level C.

references: The appeal of record-specific ğ®ğ®\mathbf{u} parameters is that the assumption of a fixed disagreement level distribution across records is relaxed and comparison data can be modelled differently across records in A. In the application to Union Army data, discussed in Section 4, this refinement greatly improves performance in two ways: first, by achieving convergence in blocks where matches could previously not be identified and, second, by recovering more true matches in all blocks, particularly among men with less common names. To see why, consider Figure 1.

references: The above measures of TPR and PPV are â€œtrueâ€ in the sense that they are drawn from expert-linked matches available for the Union Army dataset. TPR and PPV can also be estimated within the model when true matches are unavailable, as discussed in Section 3.5. Estimated rates for our specifications are listed in Table 8. Estimated TPR and PPV were available for fastLink matchings but we found they were unreliable in settings where nA<<nBmuch-less-thansubscriptğ‘›ğ´subscriptğ‘›ğµn_{A}<<n_{B}.
